title: Contributor Code of Conduct
text: contributors maintainers project, pledge respect people contribute reporting issues, posting feature requests, updating documentation, submitting pull requests patches, activities. committed making participation project harassment-free experience everyone, regardless level experience, gender, gender identity expression, sexual orientation, disability, personal appearance, body size, race, ethnicity, age, religion. Examples unacceptable behavior participants include use sexual language imagery, derogatory comments personal attacks, trolling, public private harassment, insults, unprofessional conduct. Project maintainers right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct. Project maintainers follow Code Conduct may removed project team. Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported opening issue contacting one project maintainers. Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant (http:contributor-covenant.org), version 1.0.0, available http://contributor-covenant.org/version/1/0/0/

title: CONTRIBUTING
text: love collaboration.

title: CONTRIBUTING
text: Submit issue Issues page

title: CONTRIBUTING
text: ###Scope love help developing rentrez. Bear mind, rentrez intended general-purpose wrapper Eutils API. Functions make use rentrez perform specific tasks added existing packages, form basis new ones. ###Perferred way contribute code Fork repo Github account Clone version account machine account, e.g,. git clone https://github.com/<yourgithubusername>/rentrez.git Make sure track progress upstream (.e., version rentrez ropensci/rentrez) git remote add upstream https://github.com/ropensci/rentrez.git. making changes make sure pull changes upstream either git fetch upstream merge later git pull upstream fetch merge one step Make changes (bonus points making changes new branch) Push account Submit pull request home base ropensci/rentrez

title: CONTRIBUTING
text: Get touch: david.winter@gmail.com. Please note project released Contributor Code Conduct. participating project agree abide terms. Thanks contibuting!

what: Introduction: The NCBI, entrez and rentrez.
title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: NCBI shares lot data. time document compiled, 31.7 million papers PubMed, including 6.6 million full-text records available PubMed Central. NCBI Nucleotide Database (includes GenBank) data 432 million different sequences, dbSNP describes 702 million different genetic variants. records can cross-referenced 1.86 million species NCBI taxonomy 27 thousand disease-associated records OMIM. NCBI makes data available web interface, FTP server REST API called Entrez Utilities (Eutils short). package provides functions use API, allowing users gather combine data multiple NCBI databases comfort R session script.

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: make data NCBI shares need know little databases, records contain ways can find records. NCBI provides extensive documentation databases EUtils API rentrez takes advantage . also helper functions rentrez help users learn way around NCBI’s databases. First, can use entrez_dbs() find list available databases: set functions names starting entrez_db_ can used gather information databases: Functions help learn NCBI databases instance, can get description somewhat cryptically named database ‘cdd’… … find search terms can used Sequence Read Archive (SRA) database (contains raw data sequencing projects): Just ‘helper’ functions might useful become clearer ’ve started using rentrez, let’s get started.
code: entrez_dbs() entrez_db_summary("cdd") entrez_db_searchable("sra")

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: often, first thing ’ll want rentrez search given NCBI database find records match keywords. can using function entrez_search(). simplest case just need provide database name (db) search term (term) let’s search PubMed articles R language: object returned search acts like list, can get summary contents printing . things note . First, NCBI’s server worked meant R programming language, included ‘MeSH’ term term associated programming languages. ’ll worry MeSH terms special queries later, now just note can use feature check search term interpreted way intended. Second, many ‘hits’ search unique IDs contained object. ’s optional argument retmax, controls maximum number returned values default value 20. IDs important thing returned . allow us fetch records matching IDs, gather summary data find cross-referenced records databases. access IDs vector using $ operator: want get 20 IDs can increasing ret_max argument. want get IDs thousands records match search, can use NCBI’s web history feature described .
code: r_search <- entrez_search(db="pubmed", term="R Language") r_search r_search$ids another_r_search <- entrez_search(db="pubmed", term="R Language", retmax=40) another_r_search

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: EUtils API uses special syntax build search terms. can search database specific term using format query[SEARCH FIELD], combine multiple searches using boolean operators , . instance, can find next generation sequence datasets (amazing…) ciliate Tetrahymena thermophila using organism (‘ORGN’) search field: can narrow focus records added recently (using colon specify range values): include recent records either T. thermophila ’s close relative T. borealis (using parentheses make ANDs ORs explicit). set search terms available varies databases. can get list available terms given data base entrez_db_searchable()
code: entrez_search(db="sra",               term="Tetrahymena thermophila[ORGN]",               retmax=0) entrez_search(db="sra",               term="Tetrahymena thermophila[ORGN] AND 2013:2015[PDAT]",               retmax=0) entrez_search(db="sra",               term="(Tetrahymena thermophila[ORGN] OR Tetrahymena borealis[ORGN]) AND 2013:2015[PDAT]",               retmax=0) entrez_db_searchable("sra")

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: “Filter” special field , names suggests, allows limit records returned search set filtering criteria. programmatic way find particular terms can used Filter field. However, NCBI’s website provides “advanced search” tool databases can used discover terms. example, find list possible find terms can used filter searches nucleotide database using advanced search databse. page selecting “Filter” first drop-box clicking “Show index list” allow user scroll possible filtering terms. ###Precise queries using MeSH terms addition search terms described , NCBI allows searches using Medical Subject Heading (MeSH) terms. terms create ‘controlled vocabulary’, allow users make finely controlled queries databases. instance, interested reviewing studies class anti-malarial drugs called Folic Acid Antagonists work Plasmodium vivax (particular species malarial parasite), use search: complete set MeSH terms available database NCBI. means possible download detailed information term find ways terms relate using rentrez. can search specific terms entrez_search(db="mesh", term =...) learn results search using tools described .
code: entrez_search(db   = "pubmed",               term = "(vivax malaria[MeSH]) AND (folic acid antagonists[MeSH])")

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: can see , object returned entrez_search() includes number records matching given search. means can learn little composition , trends , records stored NCBI’s databases using search utility. instance, let’s track rise scientific buzzword “connectome” PubMed, programmatically creating search terms PDAT field:
code: search_year <- function(year, term){     query <- paste(term, "AND (", year, "[PDAT])")     entrez_search(db="pubmed", term=query, retmax=0)$count }  year <- 2008:2014 papers <- sapply(year, search_year, term="Connectome", USE.NAMES=FALSE)  plot(year, papers, type='b', main="The Rise of the Connectome")

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: One strengths NCBI databases degree records one type connected records within NCBI external data sources. function entrez_link() allows users discover links records.

what: My god, it’s full of links
title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: get idea degree records NCBI cross-linked can find NCBI data associated single gene (case Amyloid Beta Precursor gene, product associated plaques form brains Alzheimer’s Disease patients). function entrez_link() can used find cross-referenced records. basic case need provide ID (id), database ID comes (dbfrom) name database find linked records (db). set last argument ‘’ can find links multiple databases: Just entrez_search returned object behaves like list, can learn little contents printing . case, information links (’s lot !): names list elements format [source_database]_[linked_database] elements contain vector linked-IDs. , want find open access publications associated gene get linked records PubMed Central: interested gene’s role diseases find links clinVar:
code: all_the_links <- entrez_link(dbfrom='gene', id=351, db='all') all_the_links all_the_links$links all_the_links$links$gene_pmc[1:10] all_the_links$links$gene_clinvar

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: know beforehand sort links ’d like find , can use db argument narrow focus call entrez_link. instance, say interested knowing RNA transcripts associated Amyloid Beta Precursor gene humans. Transcript sequences stored nucleotide database (referred nuccore EUtils), find transcripts associated given gene need set dbfrom=gene db=nuccore. object get back contains links nucleotide database generally, also special subsets database like refseq. can take advantage narrower set links find IDs match unique transcripts gene interest. can use ids calls entrez_fetch() entrez_summary() learn transcripts represent.
code: nuc_links <- entrez_link(dbfrom='gene', id=351, db='nuccore') nuc_links nuc_links$links nuc_links$links$gene_nuccore_refseqrna

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: addition finding data within NCBI, entrez_link can turn connections external databases. Perhaps interesting example finding links full text papers PubMed. example, wrote document first paper linked Amyloid Beta Precursor unique ID 25500142. can find links full text paper entrez_link setting cmd argument ‘llinks’: element linkouts object contains information external source data paper: linkout objects contains quite lot information, URL probably useful. reason, rentrez provides function linkout_urls make extracting just URL simple: full list options cmd argument given -line documentation (?entrez_link). interested finding full text records large number articles checkout package fulltext makes use multiple sources (including NCBI) discover full text articles.
code: paper_links <- entrez_link(dbfrom="pubmed", id=25500142, cmd="llinks") paper_links paper_links$linkouts linkout_urls(paper_links)

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: possible pass one ID entrez_link(). default, give single elink object containing complete set links IDs specified. , looking protein IDs related specific genes : Although behaviour might sometimes useful, means ’ve lost track protein ID linked gene ID. retain information can set by_id TRUE. gives us list elink objects, containing links single gene ID:
code: all_links_together  <- entrez_link(db="protein", dbfrom="gene", id=c("93100", "223646")) all_links_together all_links_together$links$gene_protein all_links_sep  <- entrez_link(db="protein", dbfrom="gene", id=c("93100", "223646"), by_id=TRUE) all_links_sep lapply(all_links_sep, function(x) x$links$gene_protein)

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: found unique IDs records via entrez_search entrez_link(), probably going want learn something . Eutils API two ways get information record. entrez_fetch() returns ‘full’ records varying formats entrez_summary() returns less information record, relatively simple format. often summary records information , rentrez provides functions parse summarise summary records.

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: entrez_summary() takes vector unique IDs samples want get summary information . Let’s start finding something paper describing Taxize, using PubMed ID: , object returned entrez_summary behaves like list, can extract elements using $. instance, convert PubMed ID another article identifier… …see many times article cited PubMed Central papers
code: taxize_summ <- entrez_summary(db="pubmed", id=24555091) taxize_summ taxize_summ$articleids taxize_summ$pmcrefcount

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: give entrez_summary() vector one ID ’ll get list summary records back. Let’s get Plasmodium vivax papers found entrez_search() section back, fetch summary data paper: rentrez provides helper function, extract_from_esummary() takes one elements every summary record one lists. working one… … several elements:
code: vivax_search <- entrez_search(db = "pubmed",                               term = "(vivax malaria[MeSH]) AND (folic acid antagonists[MeSH])") multi_summs <- entrez_summary(db="pubmed", id=vivax_search$ids) extract_from_esummary(multi_summs, "fulljournalname") date_and_cite <- extract_from_esummary(multi_summs, c("pubdate", "pmcrefcount",  "title")) knitr::kable(head(t(date_and_cite)), row.names=FALSE)

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: useful summary records , sometimes just don’t information need. want complete representation record can use entrez_fetch, using argument rettype specify format ’d like record .

what: Fetch DNA sequences in fasta format
title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: Let’s extend example given entrez_link() section finding transcript given gene. time fetch cDNA sequences transcripts.can start repeating steps earlier example get nucleotide IDs refseq transcripts two genes: Now can get sequences entrez_fetch, setting rettype “fasta” (list formats available database give table): Congratulations, now really huge character vector! Rather printing thousands bases can take peak top file: wanted use sequences application write file: Alternatively, want use within R session write temporary file read . case ’m using read.dna() pylogenetics package ape (executing code block vignette, don’t install package):
code: gene_ids <- c(351, 11647) linked_seq_ids <- entrez_link(dbfrom="gene", id=gene_ids, db="nuccore") linked_transripts <- linked_seq_ids$links$gene_nuccore_refseqrna head(linked_transripts) all_recs <- entrez_fetch(db="nuccore", id=linked_transripts, rettype="fasta") class(all_recs) nchar(all_recs) cat(strwrap(substr(all_recs, 1, 500)), sep="\n") write(all_recs, file="my_transcripts.fasta") temp <- tempfile() write(all_recs, temp) parsed_recs <- ape::read.dna(all_recs, temp)

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: NCBI’s databases can return records XML format. additional downloading text-representation files, entrez_fetch() can return objects parsed XML package. example, can check Taxonomy database’s record (mention amazing….) Tetrahymena thermophila, specifying want result parsed setting parsed=TRUE: package XML (installed rentrez) provides functions get information files. relatively simple records like one can use XML::xmlToList: complex records, generate deeply-nested lists, can use XPath expressions along function XML::xpathSApply extraction operatord [ [[ extract specific parts file. instance, can get scientific name taxon T. thermophila’s lineage specifying path XML name suggests, XML::xpathSApply() counterpart base R’s sapply, can used apply function nodes XML object. particularly useful function apply XML::xmlValue, returns content node: complex examples using XPath rentrez wiki
code: Tt <- entrez_search(db="taxonomy", term="(Tetrahymena thermophila[ORGN]) AND Species[RANK]") tax_rec <- entrez_fetch(db="taxonomy", id=Tt$ids, rettype="xml", parsed=TRUE) class(tax_rec) tax_list <- XML::xmlToList(tax_rec) tax_list$Taxon$GeneticCode tt_lineage <- tax_rec["//LineageEx/Taxon/ScientificName"] tt_lineage[1:4] XML::xpathSApply(tax_rec, "//LineageEx/Taxon/ScientificName", XML::xmlValue)

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: dealing large queries can time consuming pass long vectors unique IDs NCBI. avoid problem, NCBI provides feature called “web history” allows users store IDs NCBI servers refer future calls. ###Post set IDs NCBI later use: entrez_post() list many NCBI IDs want use later , can post NCBI’s severs. order provide brief example, ’m going post just one ID, omim identifier asthma: NCBI sends back information can use refer posted IDs. rentrez, information represented web_history object. Note long list IDs may receive 414 error try upload . list (come external sources rather search can save web_history object), may ‘chunk’ IDs smaller sets can processed.
code: upload <- entrez_post(db="omim", id=600807) upload

what: Get a web_history object from entrez_search or entrez_link()
title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: addition directly uploading IDs NCBI, can use web history features entrez_search entrez_link. instance, imagine wanted find sequences widely-studied gene COI snails (members taxonomic group Gastropoda): ’s lot sequences! really wanted download good idea save IDs server setting use_history TRUE (note now get web_history object along normal search result): Similarity, entrez_link() can return web_history objects using cmd neighbor_history. Let’s find genetic variants (clinvar database) associated asthma (using OMIM ID identified earlier): can see, instead returning lists IDs linked database (default), entrez_link() now returns list web_histories.
code: entrez_search(db="nuccore", term="COI[Gene] AND Gastropoda[ORGN]") snail_coi <- entrez_search(db="nuccore", term="COI[Gene] AND Gastropoda[ORGN]", use_history=TRUE) snail_coi snail_coi$web_history asthma_clinvar <- entrez_link(dbfrom="omim", db="clinvar", cmd="neighbor_history", id=600807) asthma_clinvar$web_histories

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: IDs stored NCBI’s servers, going want something . functions entrez_fetch() entrez_summary() entrez_link() can use web_history objects exactly way use IDs. , repeat last example (finding variants linked asthma), time using ID uploaded earlier … want get genetic information variants need map clinvar IDs SNP IDs: really wanted also use web_history objects download thousands COI sequences. downloading large sets data, good idea take advantage arguments retmax restart split request smaller chunks. instance, get first 200 sequences 50-sequence chunks: (note: code block executed part vignette save time bandwidth):
code: asthma_variants <- entrez_link(dbfrom="omim", db="clinvar", cmd="neighbor_history", web_history=upload) asthma_variants snp_links <- entrez_link(dbfrom="clinvar", db="snp",                           web_history=asthma_variants$web_histories$omim_clinvar,                          cmd="neighbor_history") snp_summ <- entrez_summary(db="snp", web_history=snp_links$web_histories$clinvar_snp) knitr::kable(extract_from_esummary(snp_summ, c("chr", "fxn_class", "global_maf"))) for( seq_start in seq(1,200,50)){     recs <- entrez_fetch(db="nuccore", web_history=snail_coi$web_history,                          rettype="fasta", retmax=50, retstart=seq_start)     cat(recs, file="snail_coi.fasta", append=TRUE)     cat(seq_start+49, "sequences downloaded\r") }

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: default, NCBI limits users making 3 requests per second (rentrez enforces limit). Users register “API key” able make ten requests per second. Getting one keys simple, just need register “ncbi” account click button account settings page. API key, rentrez allow take advantage . one-cases, simple adding api_key argument given function call. (Note examples executed part document, API key used real one). cases want use API several calls NCBI. rentrez makes easy allowing set environment variable ,ENTREZ_KEY. value set key rentrez use requests NCBI. set value single R session can use function set_entrez_key(). set value confirm available. use rentrez often edit .Renviron file (see r help(Startup) description file) include key. mean requests send take advantage API key. long API key set one methods, rentrez allow make ten requests per second.
code: entrez_link(db="protein", dbfrom="gene", id=93100, api_key ="ABCD123") set_entrez_key("ABCD123") Sys.getenv("ENTREZ_KEY") ENTREZ_KEY=ABCD123

what: Slowing rentrez down when you hit the rate-limit
title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: rentrez won’t let send requests NCBI rate higher rate-limit, sometimes possible arrive close together produce errors. using rentrez functions loop find rate-limiting errors occuring, may consider adding call Sys.sleep(0.1) message sent NCBI. ensure stay beloe rate limit.

title: Rentrez Tutorial
text: tutorial introduced core functions rentrez, almost limitless ways put together. Check wiki specific examples, sure read inline-documentation function. run problem rentrez, just need help package Eutils please contact us opening issue github repository

title: Entrez in R
text: rentrez provides functions work NCBI Eutils API search, download data , otherwise interact NCBI databases.

title: Entrez in R
text: rentrez CRAN, can get latest stable release install.packages("rentrez"). repository sometimes little ahead CRAN version, want latest (possibly greatest) version can install current github version using Hadley Wickham’s devtools.
code: library(devtools) install_github("ropensci/rentrez")

title: Entrez in R
text: functions exported rentrez documented, README package vignette provide examples use functions together part workflow. API well-documented. sure read official documentation get API. particular, aware NCBI’s usage policies try limit large requests peak (USA) times (rentrez takes care limiting number requests per second, setting appropriate entrez tool name request). Hopefully README, package’s vignette -line documentation, provide enough information get started rentrez. need help, discover bug rentrez please let us know, either one contact methods described , filing issue

title: Entrez in R
text: many cases, something interesting EUtils take multiple calls. examples functions work together (check package vignette others).

what: Getting data from that great paper you’ve just read
title: Entrez in R
text: Let’s say ’ve just read paper evolution Hox genes, Di-Poi et al. (2010), want get data required replicate results. First, need unique ID paper pubmed (PMID). Unfortunately, many journals don’t give PMIDS papers, can use entrez_search find paper using doi field: Now, sorts data available NCBI database paper? case data links element: character vectors object contain unique IDs records named databases. functions try make useful bits returned files available users, also return original file case want dive XML . case ’ll get protein sequences fasta files, using ’ entrez_fetch:
code: library(rentrez) hox_paper <- entrez_search(db="pubmed", term="10.1038/nature08789[doi]") hox_paper$ids # [1] "20203609" hox_data <- entrez_link(db="all", id=hox_paper$ids, dbfrom="pubmed") hox_data # elink object with contents: #  $links: IDs for linked records from NCBI # hox_data$links # elink result with information from 14 databases: #  [1] pubmed_medgen              pubmed_pmc_refs            #  [3] pubmed_pubmed              pubmed_pubmed_alsoviewed   #  [5] pubmed_pubmed_citedin      pubmed_pubmed_combined     #  [7] pubmed_pubmed_five         pubmed_pubmed_reviews      #  [9] pubmed_pubmed_reviews_five pubmed_mesh_major          # [11] pubmed_nuccore             pubmed_nucleotide          # [13] pubmed_protein             pubmed_taxonomy_entrez hox_proteins <- entrez_fetch(db="protein", id=hox_data$links$pubmed_protein, rettype="fasta") # No encoding supplied: defaulting to UTF-8. cat(substr(hox_proteins, 1, 237)) # >gi|290760438|gb|ADD54588.1| HOXA10, partial [Saiphos equalis] # MACSESPAANSFLVDSLISSASVRGEGGGGGGGGGGAGGGGGEGGGGGGGVYYPNNSSVYLPQTSELSYG # LPSYGLFPVLSKRNEGPSQSMVPASHTYMSGMEVWLDPPRSCRLEDPESPQATSCSFTPNIKEENSYCLY # DSDKGPKEATATDLSTFPRLTSEVCSMNNV

what: Retrieving datasets associated a particular organism.
title: Entrez in R
text: like spiders. let’s say want learn little New Zealand’s endemic “black widow” katipo. Specifically, past katipo split two species, can make phylogeny test idea? first step use function entrez_search find datasets include katipo sequences. popset database sequences arising phylogenetic population-level studies, let’s start . search count total number hits returned search term. can use entrez_summary learn little datasets. rentrez parse xml list esummary records, list entry corresponding one IDs passed. case get six records, see one contains like : can extract specific elements list summary records extract_from_esummary: Let’s just get two mitochondrial loci (COI trnL), using entrez_fetch: “fetched” results fasta formatted characters, can written disk easily: ’ve got sequences can want , wanted phylogeny can entirly within R. get nice tree legible tip labels ’m gong use stringr extract just species names ape built root neighbor joining tree:
code: library(rentrez) katipo_search <- entrez_search(db="popset", term="Latrodectus katipo[Organism]") katipo_search$count # [1] 6 katipo_summs <- entrez_summary(db="popset", id=katipo_search$ids) katipo_summs # List of  6 esummary records. First record: #  #  $`167843272` # esummary result with 17 items: #  [1] uid        caption    title      extra      gi         settype    #  [7] createdate updatedate flags      taxid      authors    article    # [13] journal    strain     statistics properties oslt titles <- extract_from_esummary(katipo_summs, "title") unname(titles) # [1] "Latrodectus katipo 18S ribosomal RNA gene, partial sequence; internal transcribed spacer 1, 5.8S ribosomal RNA gene, and internal transcribed spacer 2, complete sequence; and 28S ribosomal RNA gene, partial sequence." # [2] "Latrodectus katipo cytochrome oxidase subunit 1 (COI) gene, partial cds; mitochondrial."                                                                                                                                  # [3] "Latrodectus 18S ribosomal RNA gene, partial sequence; internal transcribed spacer 1, 5.8S ribosomal RNA gene, and internal transcribed spacer 2, complete sequence; and 28S ribosomal RNA gene, partial sequence."        # [4] "Latrodectus cytochrome oxidase subunit 1 (COI) gene, partial cds; mitochondrial."                                                                                                                                         # [5] "Latrodectus tRNA-Leu (trnL) gene, partial sequence; and NADH dehydrogenase subunit 1 (ND1) gene, partial cds; mitochondrial."                                                                                             # [6] "Theridiidae cytochrome oxidase subunit I (COI) gene, partial cds; mitochondrial." COI_ids <- katipo_search$ids[c(2,6)] trnL_ids <- katipo_search$ids[5] COI <- entrez_fetch(db="popset", id=COI_ids, rettype="fasta") # No encoding supplied: defaulting to UTF-8. trnL <- entrez_fetch(db="popset", id=trnL_ids, rettype="fasta") # No encoding supplied: defaulting to UTF-8. write(COI, "Test/COI.fasta") write(trnL, "Test/trnL.fasta") library(ape) tf <- tempfile() write(COI, tf) coi <- read.dna(tf, format="fasta") coi_aligned <- muscle(coi) tree <- nj(dist.dna(coi_aligned)) tree$tip.label <- stringr::str_extract(tree$tip.label, "Steatoda [a-z]+|Latrodectus [a-z]+") plot( root(tree, outgroup="Steatoda grossa" ), cex=0.8)

title: Entrez in R
text: NCBI provides search history features, can useful dealing large lists IDs repeated searches. example, imagine wanted learn something SNPs non-recombing portion Y chromsome humans. first find SNPs using entrez_search, using “CHR” (chromosome) “CPOS” (position chromosome) specify region interest. (syntax search terms described vignette documentation entrez_search): wrote little 200 000 SNPs. ’s probably good idea set retmax 200 000 just download identifiers. Instead, store list IDs NCBI’s server refer later calles functions like entrez_link entrez_fetch accept web history object. can see, result search now includes web_history object. can use object refer IDs later calls. Heree just fetch complete records first 5 SNPs. records come us parsed XML objects, futher process XML library write disk later use.
code: snp_search <- entrez_search(db="snp",                              term="(Y[CHR] AND Homo[ORGN]) NOT 10001:2781479[CPOS]") snp_search # Entrez search result with 234154 hits (object contains 20 IDs and no web_history object) #  Search term (as translated):  (Y[CHR] AND "Homo"[Organism]) NOT 10001[CHRPOS] :  ... snp_search <- entrez_search(db="snp",                              term="(Y[CHR] AND Homo[ORGN]) NOT 10001:2781479[CPOS]",                              use_history = TRUE) snp_search # Entrez search result with 234154 hits (object contains 20 IDs and a web_history object) #  Search term (as translated):  (Y[CHR] AND "Homo"[Organism]) NOT 10001[CHRPOS] :  ... recs <- entrez_fetch(db="snp", web_history=snp_search$web_history, retmax=5, rettype="xml", parsed=TRUE) class(recs) # [1] "XMLInternalDocument" "XMLAbstractDocument"

title: Entrez in R
text: examples required background information databases NCBI offer, can searched. rentrez provides set functions names starting entrez_db help discover information interactive session. First , entrez_dbs() gives list database names names little opaque, can get descriptive information entrez_db_summary() entrez_db_searchable() lets discover fields available search terms given database. get back named-list, names fields. element additional information named search field (can also use .data.frame create dataframe, one search-field per row): Finally, entrez_db_links takes database name, returns list NCBI databases might contain linked-records.
code: entrez_dbs() #  [1] "pubmed"          "protein"         "nuccore"         #  [4] "nucleotide"      "nucgss"          "nucest"          #  [7] "structure"       "genome"          "annotinfo"       # [10] "assembly"        "bioproject"      "biosample"       # [13] "blastdbinfo"     "books"           "cdd"             # [16] "clinvar"         "clone"           "gap"             # [19] "gapplus"         "grasp"           "dbvar"           # [22] "epigenomics"     "gene"            "gds"             # [25] "geoprofiles"     "homologene"      "medgen"          # [28] "mesh"            "ncbisearch"      "nlmcatalog"      # [31] "omim"            "orgtrack"        "pmc"             # [34] "popset"          "probe"           "proteinclusters" # [37] "pcassay"         "biosystems"      "pccompound"      # [40] "pcsubstance"     "pubmedhealth"    "seqannot"        # [43] "snp"             "sra"             "taxonomy"        # [46] "unigene"         "gencoll"         "gtr" entrez_db_summary("cdd") #  DbName: cdd #  MenuName: Conserved Domains #  Description: Conserved Domain Database #  DbBuild: Build150814-1106.1 #  Count: 50648 #  LastUpdate: 2015/08/14 18:42 search_fields <- entrez_db_searchable("pmc") search_fields$GRNT #  Name: GRNT #  FullName: Grant Number #  Description: NIH Grant Numbers #  TermCount: 2272841 #  IsDate: N #  IsNumerical: N #  SingleToken: Y #  Hierarchy: N #  IsHidden: N entrez_db_links("omim") # Databases with linked records for database 'omim' #  [1] biosample   biosystems  books       clinvar     dbvar       #  [6] gene        genetests   geoprofiles gtr         homologene  # [11] mapview     medgen      medgen      nuccore     nucest      # [16] nucgss      omim        pcassay     pccompound  pcsubstance # [21] pmc         protein     pubmed      pubmed      sra         # [26] structure   unigene

title: Entrez in R
text: one little trivial, can also use entrez search pubmed EUtils API allows limit searches year paper published. gives chance find trendiest -omics going around (quite lot repeated searching, want run version sure peak times). Let’s start making function finds number records matching given search term several years (using mindate maxdate terms Eutils API): can fetch data term , searching term, find total number papers published year: ’s data, let’s plot : Giving us… well :  package part richer suite called fulltext, along several packages, provides ability search retrieve full text open access scholarly articles.
code: library(rentrez) papers_by_year <- function(years, search_term){     return(sapply(years, function(y) entrez_search(db="pubmed",term=search_term, mindate=y, maxdate=y, retmax=0)$count)) } years <- 1990:2015 total_papers <- papers_by_year(years, "") omics <- c("genomic", "epigenomic", "metagenomic", "proteomic", "transcriptomic", "pharmacogenomic", "connectomic" ) trend_data <- sapply(omics, function(t) papers_by_year(years, t)) trend_props <- trend_data/total_papers library(reshape) library(ggplot2) trend_df <- melt(data.frame(years, trend_props), id.vars="years") p <- ggplot(trend_df, aes(years, value, colour=variable)) p + geom_line(size=1) + scale_y_log10("number of papers")

text: bdata character, containing citation data.  citation must represented pipe-delimited format  journal_title|year|volume|first_page|author_name|your_key| final field "your_key" arbitrary, can used see fit. Fields can left empty, sure keep 6 pipes. db character, database search. Defaults pubmed, database currently available retmode character, file format retrieve. Defaults xml,  per API documentation, though note API returns plain text config vector configuration options passed httr::GET

title: Get links to datasets related to records from an NCBI database — entrez_link
text: dbfrom character Name database Id(s) originate web_history web_history object id vector unique ID(s) records database db. db character Name database search links (use ""  search databases available db. entrez_db_links allows discover databases might linked information (see examples). cmd link function use. Allowed values include neighbor (default). Returns set IDs db linked   input IDs dbfrom. neighbor_score. `neighbor'', additionally returns similarity scores. neighbor_history. `neighbor', returns web history objects. acheck. Returns list linked databases available NCBI set IDs. ncheck. Checks existence links within single database. lcheck. Checks external (.e. outside NCBI) links. llinks. Returns list external links ID, excluding links   provided libraries. llinkslib. 'llinks' additionally includes links provided   libraries. prlinks. 'llinks' returns primary external link   ID. by_id logical FALSE (default) return single  elink objects containing links provided ids.  Alternatively, TRUE return list elink objects, one  ID id. config vector configuration options passed httr::GET ... character Additional terms add request, see NCBI documentation linked references complete list

title: Get links to datasets related to records from an NCBI database — entrez_link

title: Search the NCBI databases using EUtils — entrez_search
text: NCBI uses search term syntax search terms can associated  specific search field square brackets. , instance ``Homo[ORGN]'' denotes search Homo ``Organism'' field. names definitions fields can identified using entrez_db_searchable. Searches can make use several fields combining via boolean operators , . , using search term``((Homo[ORGN] APP[GENE]) Review[PTYP])'' PubMed identify articles matching gene APP humans, exclude review articles. examples use search terms, specific MeSH terms precise searching,  given package vignette. rentrez handles special characters URL encoding (e.g. replacing spaces plus signs) client side, need include search term Therentrez tutorial provides tips make  searches NCBI. particular, sections uses "Filter" field MeSH terms may formulating precise searches.

title: Search the NCBI databases using EUtils — entrez_search
text: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK25499/#_chapter4_ESearch_

title: Search the NCBI databases using EUtils — entrez_search
code: if (FALSE) {    query <- "Gastropoda[Organism] AND COI[Gene]"    web_env_search <- entrez_search(db="nuccore", query, use_history=TRUE)    cookie <- web_env_search$WebEnv    qk <- web_env_search$QueryKey     snail_coi <- entrez_fetch(db = "nuccore", WebEnv = cookie, query_key = qk,                              file_format = "fasta", retmax = 10) } if (FALSE) {  fly_id <- entrez_search(db="taxonomy", term="Drosophila") #Oh, right. There is a genus and a subgenus name Drosophila... #how can we limit this search (tax_fields <- entrez_db_searchable("taxonomy")) #"RANK" loots promising tax_fields$RANK entrez_search(db="taxonomy", term="Drosophila & Genus[RANK]") }

what: Get summaries of objects in NCBI datasets from a unique ID — entrez_summary
title: Get summaries of objects in NCBI datasets from a unique ID — entrez_summary
text: NCBI offer two distinct formats summary documents. Version 1.0 relatively limited summary database record based  shared Document Type Definition. Version 1.0 summaries available XML available newer databases Version 2.0 summaries generally contain information given record, database distinct format. 2.0 summaries  available records databases JSON XML files.  version 0.4, rentrez fetches version 2.0 summaries default uses JSON exchange format (JSON object can easily converted native R types). Existing scripts relied structure naming "Version 1.0" summary files can updated setting new version argument "1.0".

title: Get summaries of objects in NCBI datasets from a unique ID — entrez_summary
code: entrez_summary(   db,   id = NULL,   web_history = NULL,   version = c("2.0", "1.0"),   always_return_list = FALSE,   retmode = NULL,   config = NULL,   ... )

title: Get summaries of objects in NCBI datasets from a unique ID — entrez_summary
text: db character Name database search id vector unique ID(s) records database db. case sequence databases IDs can take form NCBI accession followed version number (eg AF123456.1 AF123456.2) web_history web_history object version either 1.0 2.0 see description always_return_list logical, return list  esummary objects even one ID provided (see description note option) retmode either "xml" "json". default, xml used version 1.0 records, json version 2.0. config vector configuration options passed httr::GET ... character Additional terms add request, see NCBI documentation linked references complete list

code: if (FALSE) {  pop_ids = c("307082412", "307075396", "307075338", "307075274")  pop_summ <- entrez_summary(db="popset", id=pop_ids)  extract_from_esummary(pop_summ, "title")    # clinvar example  res <- entrez_search(db = "clinvar", term = "BRCA1", retmax=10)  cv <- entrez_summary(db="clinvar", id=res$ids)  cv  extract_from_esummary(cv, "title", simplify=FALSE)  extract_from_esummary(cv, "trait_set")[1:2]   extract_from_esummary(cv, "gene_sort")  }

code: # \donttest{ hox_paper <- entrez_search(db="pubmed", term="10.1038/nature08789[doi]") hox_rel <- entrez_link(db="pubmed", dbfrom="pubmed", id=hox_paper$ids) recs <- entrez_fetch(db="pubmed",                         id=hox_rel$links$pubmed_pubmed[1:3],                         rettype="xml") parse_pubmed_xml(recs) #> List of 3 pubmed records #>  Di-Poï, Nicolas et al. (2010).  Nature. 464:99-103  #>  Feiner, Nathalie. & Wood, Natalie J. (2019).  Evolution & development. 21:218-228  #>  Woltering, Joost M et al. (2009).  Developmental biology. 332:82-9  # }

title: rentrez — rentrez
text: rentrez provides functions search , discover download data NCBI's databases using EUtils function.

title: rentrez — rentrez
text: Users expected know little bit EUtils API, well documented: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK25500/ NCBI ban IPs use EUtils within user guidelines. particular /enumerated  /item  send three request per second (rentrez enforces limit)  /item  plan sending sequence ~100 requests, outside peak times US  /item  large requests use web history method (see examples entrez_search use entrez_post upload IDs)
